awd_titl_txt: Discovery and Dynamical Classification of Accreting Compact Objects with the Zwicky Transient Facility
awd_abstract_narration:
Rebecca Phillipson is awarded a Mathematical and Physical Sciences Ascending Postdoctoral Research Fellowship (MPS-Ascend) to conduct a program of research and education at Washington University. Dr. Phillipson plans to take advantage of upcoming large scale optical studies, like the NSF’s Vera C. Rubin Observatory Legacy Survey of Space and Time.   She has demonstrated recurrence analysis methods from nonlinear dynamics are capable of distinguishing between deterministic, stochastic, and chaotic signals in X-ray Binary Stars and Active Galactic Nuclei.  Dr. Phillipson plans to broaden participation in the astrophysics field in several ways.  She will mentor students participating in the Pre-Major in Astronomy program which gives opportunities for students from underrepresented groups to perform cutting edge research.

Phillipson’s preliminary work suggests that an ensemble study of stellar light curves, with the recurrence methods, paired with machine learning, will result in novel classifications of variable sources based on their dynamical variability.  The numerical approaches open a new discovery space for detection of quasi-periodic variable objects.   She will partner with the eScience Institute to develop an accessible website for the dissemination of the scientific results from her research program.  A key feature of her data access plan is enabling visually impaired scientists to interact with the data by using sounds to facilitate feature detection and analysis.   This approach, called sonification, uses existing software tools to map scientific data to acoustic sequences.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Zwicky Transient Facility (ZTF) is an ongoing, NSF-funded, optical time-domain survey that uses the Palomar 48-inch Schmidt telescope, employing a wide-field camera covering a 47 deg2 field of view. The ZTF survey has been ongoing since it began in March 2018, resulting in multi-year light curves with hundreds to thousands of epochs in 3 optical bands for more than a billion sources in which we can apply novel statistical analyses. Using ZTF and supplemental analog light curves from X-ray light curves down-sampled to ZTF cadence, we have demonstrated that recurrence plot (RP) analysis is a viable novel time series technique that can distinguish complex modes of variability, particularly those intrinsic to Active Galactic Nuclei (AGN) and X-ray Binaries (XRBs).

We tested the premise that changes in accretion states result in changes in variability patterns. With an undergraduate researcher, we considered the well-known black hole XRB, Cygnus X-1, which has a prolific amount of archival data detailing its spectral changes over various accretion states. As a result, we were able to generate RPs as a function of time and compare how changes in the RP features correlated with the spectral changes of the source (Broadbent & Phillipson 2024). This established the premise that spectral features are imprinted in the light curves of accreting systems and set expectations for what those differences may be between accretion states in preparation for an ensemble study with ZTF.

We also developed methodology to modify RPs for irregular cadence light curves. Since RPs typically require the input time series to be evenly sampled, we adapted RPs to accommodate irregularly sampled light curves following procedures typical in neuroscience, also in collaboration with undergraduate researchers. Using unsupervised machine learning clustering methods on the RP features of ZTF light curves of Swift-BAT selected AGN, we found distinct differences segregated by the physical properties of the AGN (as presented in AAS proceedings by Phillipson et al. 2024 and De Los Angeles et al. 2023). We also found that the RPs themselves can be treated as images, which enables the application of a convolutional neural network (CNN) to perform image recognition. We demonstrated how successful a CNN would be at classifying RPs of the different states of the black hole XRB, GRS 1915+105, which exhibits at least 12 unique variability classes. We found a CNN applied to RPs (accommodating ZTF-like cadence) could distinguish stochastic, periodic, and chaotic states with greater than 90% accuracy of evenly sampled time series, and with greater than 70% accuracy with ZTF-like cadence (as presented in AAS proceedings by Phillipson et al. 2023).

Our Broader Impacts activities focused on the goal of developing a diverse, globally competitive STEM workforce by involving undergraduate students into astronomy research through the UW Pre-MAP program, recruiting students from outside the field into astronomy through data science applications, and using sonification in our research projects. This grant supported mentorship of five undergraduate students in total through the UW Pre-MAP Program, the Villanova Freshmen Match Program, as well as paid and for-credit research, leading to a first-author publication by a student in a peer-reviewed research journal, a first-author research note by a student in the Villanova Reseearch Journal, four contributed presentations by students at a research conference, several colloquia and a plenary by the PI to diverse and international audiences on novel time series methodologies and a budding program of sonfiication of 2D data results at Villanova University.
